channel.title: Thanks for the help people, close please
channel.description: Hi, I was wondering if anyone could tell me/link me to a good Java decompiler. All of the ones I've been downloading are either corrupt or broken or just really bad. I'd really appreciate it thanks :P. Oh and it needs to be free >< Solved, thanks guys.

item.title: Thanks for the help people, close please
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

vortex:

The message body was left empty.

Sorry what? I’m confused:.

Read full topic

item.title: Thanks for the help people, close please
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:24, topic:447597”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=550496.msg4035860#msg4035860 date=1341193388]

http://thehackernews.com/2011/08/jd-gui-fast-java-decompiler-download.html
JD-Gui

Links down for the actual dl, I tried it earlier. Don’t suppose you have a copy of it you’d be willing to upload? Its exactly what I’m looking for, I had something similar to this years ago and had this type of decompiler in mind from the start.

why can’t you just use jad/jode and open the output in an ide…?

In computing, a graphical user interface (GUI, commonly pronounced gooey[1]) is a type of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices using images rather than text commands. GUIs can be used in computers, hand-held devices such as MP3 players, portable media players or gaming devices, household appliances and office equipment. A GUI represents the information and actions available to a user through graphical icons and visual indicators such as secondary notation, as opposed to text-based interfaces, typed command labels or text navigation. The actions are usually performed through direct manipulation of the graphical elements.[2]

Do I really need to explain what the point behind a gui is to you as I suspect you already know what its for. I prefer using things with guis for things like this lol.

Thanks Fridder >.<, I didn’t read the lil bit at the top I just assumed when it said classpathe it meant Jdk or something haha. I really appreciate the post, thanks again.
[/quote]
my point was is that you already have a ui editor (i presume), so why not just open the files with in the editor - or if it’s an ide, load it as a project.

edit: if you’re afraid of terminal applications, then i really doubt you’re going to get very far hacking up decompiled bytecode[/quote]
didn’t know you could do that tbh lol.
I don’t know much but I’m trying to learn. Its not always about setting out to what you aim to achieve, if I fail at what I am to achieve then at least I can say that I’ve tried and I will always have the opportunity to come back to it later, at least I’ll have a better knowledge about it for next time.

Skyro:

You the JAD Decompiler, then just put it on your desktop. Drag the .class file onto the Jad.exe and it decompiles and adds a .jad file to your desktop which you open with notepad, or notepad++.

Thanks good to know:).

Read full topic
item.source: Thanks for the help people, close please

item.title: Thanks for the help people, close please
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:23, topic:447597”][quote author=t4 link=topic=550496.msg4035764#msg4035764 date=1341188030]

http://thehackernews.com/2011/08/jd-gui-fast-java-decompiler-download.html
JD-Gui

Links down for the actual dl, I tried it earlier. Don’t suppose you have a copy of it you’d be willing to upload? Its exactly what I’m looking for, I had something similar to this years ago and had this type of decompiler in mind from the start.

why can’t you just use jad/jode and open the output in an ide…?
[/quote]

In computing, a graphical user interface (GUI, commonly pronounced gooey[1]) is a type of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices using images rather than text commands. GUIs can be used in computers, hand-held devices such as MP3 players, portable media players or gaming devices, household appliances and office equipment. A GUI represents the information and actions available to a user through graphical icons and visual indicators such as secondary notation, as opposed to text-based interfaces, typed command labels or text navigation. The actions are usually performed through direct manipulation of the graphical elements.[2]

Do I really need to explain what the point behind a gui is to you as I suspect you already know what its for. I prefer using things with guis for things like this lol.

Thanks Fridder >.<, I didn’t read the lil bit at the top I just assumed when it said classpathe it meant Jdk or something haha. I really appreciate the post, thanks again.[/quote]
my point was is that you already have a ui editor (i presume), so why not just open the files with in the editor - or if it’s an ide, load it as a project.

edit: if you’re afraid of terminal applications, then i really doubt you’re going to get very far hacking up decompiled bytecode

Read full topic

A GUI represents the information and actions available to a user through graphical icons and visual indicators such as secondary notation, as opposed to text-based interfaces, typed command labels or text navigation. The actions are usually performed through direct manipulation of the graphical elements.[2]
Do I really need to explain what the point behind a gui is to you as I suspect you already know what its for. I prefer using things with guis for things like this lol.

Thanks Fridder >.<, I didn’t read the lil bit at the top I just assumed when it said classpathe it meant Jdk or something haha. I really appreciate the post, thanks again.

item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Kidpaparoach:

In all honesty I’m only intrested in ones with a GUI. Theirs simply too many files I want to decompile/read and I personally want a gui in general aha. Why are they for the most part terminal based anyways?

terminal-based applications can be automated a lot easier.

Bowser jr:

Kid: Just use a wildcard *

yes

Read full topic
